verses.verse: ((1 Of the enemies of the Church.7 And of the vocation of the Gentiles.) ) Oh, the (He meaneth that part of Ethiopia, which lieth toward the sea, which was so full of ships that the sails (which he compareth to wings) seemed to shadow the sea.) land shadowing with wings, which is beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,

Sending ambassadors by the sea, even in vessels of (Which in those countries were great, insomuch as they made ships of them for swiftness.) reeds upon the waters, saying, (This may be taken, that they sent others to comfort the Jews, and to promise them help against their enemies, and so the Lord did threaten to take away their strength, that the Jews should not trust therein: or that they did solicit the Egyptians, and promised them aid to go against Judah.) Go, ye swift messengers, to a nation that is scattered abroad, and spoiled, unto a terrible (To wit, the Jews, who because of Godâ€™s plague, made all other nations afraid of the like, as God threatened, Deut. 28:37.) people from their beginning even hitherto: a nation by little and little even trodden under foot: whose land the (Meaning, the Assyrians, as Isa. 8:7.) floods have spoiled.

All ye the inhabitants of the world, and dwellers in the earth, shall see when (When the Lord prepared to fight against the Ethiopians.) he setteth up a sign in the mountains, and when he bloweth the trumpet, ye shall hear.

For so the Lord said unto me, I will (I will stay a while from punishing the wicked.) rest and behold in my tabernacle, as (Which two seasons are most profitable for the ripening of fruits, whereby he meaneth, that he will seem to favor them, and give them abundance for a time, but he will suddenly cut them off.) the heat drying up the rain, and as a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.
For afore the harvest, when the flour is finished, and the fruit is ripening in the flour, then he shall cut down the branches with hooks, and shall take away, and cut off the boughs:

They shall be left together unto the fowls of the mountains, and to the (Not only men shall contemn them, but the brute beasts.) beasts of the earth: for the fowl shall summer upon it, and every beast of the earth shall winter upon it.

At that time shall a (Meaning, that God will pity his Church, and receive that little remnant as an offering unto himself.) present be brought unto the Lord of hosts (a people that is scattered abroad, and spoiled, and of a terrible people from their beginning hitherto, a nation by little and little even trodden under foot, whose land the rivers have spoiled) to the place of the name of the Lord of hosts, even the mount Zion.
